awd_titl_txt: The Development of Teaching and Social Learning Across Cultures
awd_abstract_narration:
Variation in human cultures is unique among animals in its extent, complexity, and modification over generations. Humans display a wide repertoire of socially acquired and transmitted behaviors that vary between groups and change over time. Adaptations for social learning - acquiring, creating, and transmitting cultural knowledge - provide the foundation for human culture. These learning mechanisms should be flexible, enabling individuals to respond to diverse cultural contexts. The objective of this cross-cultural research project is to study the psychological processes that allow us to learn, create, and transmit culture. Continuity and variation in child development within and across populations will be documented and explained. Multiple methods - observation, interviews, and experiments - will be used to examine the psychological foundations of cultural transmission practices (teaching) and acquisition strategies (social learning) across cultures. This project partners five developmental psychologists, two evolutionary anthropologists, and an economic psychologist, all with expertise in cross-cultural research. The dearth of systematic research outside of Western cultural contexts presents a major impediment to theoretical progress in the psychological sciences. There is a need for a new path forward in developmental psychological science to better understand global diversity in human development. The results of these studies have the potential to inform the development of international education programs by increasing understanding of variation in teaching and social learning practices around the world, allowing teachers to adapt to the diverse ways that people learn. This research team will work closely with local communities, at our domestic and international field sites, to contribute to the preservation of information about the beliefs, values, and practices of these unique cultural contexts. This breadth and depth of study will help strengthen communities in the United States and elsewhere by showing ways for them to connect, grow and adapt. 

A comprehensive account of teaching and early social learning requires systematic study of childrearing practices and beliefs. The objective of this research is to document and explain continuity and variation in teaching practices and social learning strategies within and across populations that represent the diversity of childrearing practices. This research examines the interaction between the teaching practices of caregiving adults and peers and children's social learning across populations. First, naturally occurring teaching and social learning practices will be examined using focused following, and structured interview data on beliefs about teaching and social learning will be collected. Second, standardized observational data will be collected to assess the teaching practices of adults and peers in the context of imitation and joint problem solving tasks. The naturalistic and standardized assessments of teaching practices will be compared to children's social learning. The observational and experimental data will be compared to examine the extent to which the teaching practices assessed in experimental tasks are representative of teaching practices that occurs in everyday life. Variability in teaching style depending on content, difficulty, and age and status of the learner will be examined. This research will provide the first systematic cross-cultural account of teaching by caregiving adults and peers and children's social learning. Collecting observational, interview, and experimental data will yield a far richer picture of cultural continuity and variation in teaching and learning. This project is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Variation in human cultures is unique in its extent, complexity, and modification over generations. Humans display a wide repertoire of socially acquired and transmitted behaviors that vary between groups and change over time. Cumulative culture is a process by which innovations are added to a current body of knowledge, making it increasingly complex as it is passed down through generations. This process allows for the accumulation of solutions to problems that can be modified and combined to create new technologies. Adaptations for social learning - acquiring, creating, and transmitting cultural knowledge - provide the foundation for human culture. These learning mechanisms should be flexible, enabling individuals to respond to diverse cultural contexts. 

Thus far, the dearth of systematic research outside of Western cultural contexts has presented a major impediment to theoretical progress in the psychological sciences. The objective of this international research project was to document cultural variation in the cognitive and cultural processes underpinning cumulative culture: teaching and social learning. This project was conducted in 12 countries: USA, Mexico, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Ghana, Ethiopia, the Republic of the Congo, India, Malaysia, Australia, and Vanuatu. The cross-cultural data collected for this project enrich our understanding of cognitive and social development as well as cumulative culture - one of humanity?s unique features.

Scientific Merit

Documenting Cultural Variation in Children?s Social Learning and Parent/Peer Teaching

Across the globe, learning and teaching occur in many different ways in many different environments. Culture-specific practices, beliefs, and attitudes may have a marked impact on how children learn from others. Children who go to school from a young age have vastly different learning experiences, including interactions with peers and teachers, than children who do not. We developed a comprehensive and systematic range of cognitive and social developmental tasks to study how children imitate and teach others. These tasks include ones in which children are required to learn how to solve novel problems, regulate their behaviors, and teach others a recently learned skill. Recording these behaviors allows us to address several questions, including: Does culture impact the extent to which children copy others? What are the different ways that children and caregivers across populations teach others? Addressing these questions helps to explore and document the diversity of social learning and teaching methods used by humans worldwide.

The Impact of Formal Education on Children?s Social Learning and Teaching

Formal education is a structured and systematic form of cultural transmission, transmitting information to students by trained teachers. Access to formal education is expanding globally and is significantly shaping childhood experiences. What are the implications of this access to schools and education for children across the world? How will this impact children?s cognitive development and learning abilities? School attendance has a marked impact on a diverse range of cognitive processes including executive functions & self-regulation (processes related to behavioral attention and control), creativity, and memory. By studying populations with varying participation in, and access to, formal education, we are able to measure whether, and how, it shapes children?s social learning and teaching behaviors. Data on children?s numeracy and literacy skills, length of attendance at school, and parental education allow us to assess how these factors contribute to children?s learning and teaching practices.

Our data inform our understanding of the learning processes that enable cultural acquisition and transmission. These learning processes (exploration, observation, participation, imitation, and instruction) are universal but occur in different forms and frequencies within and between populations. Our data reveal substantial variation in teaching styles across populations, and reflect children?s age and task demands, supporting broader definitions of teaching behaviors to capture global diversity. Several tasks included in this study exemplified the dual skills needed for cumulative culture: high fidelity imitation and innovation. Imitation is critical to the preservation and transmission of innovations, and children develop exceptional capacities for both of these. In addition, we found support for distinct memory processes that support self-regulatory outcomes, trends that held even when accounting for variation in schooling exposure. 

Broader Impacts

A core obstacle to large-scale cross-cultural research is developing the infrastructure to conduct systematic research in diverse populations. This requires coordinating scientists and research assistants spread across many time zones and countries in multiple languages. Our project team consisted of scientists from international institutions and diverse disciplines working together in a coordinated network spanning five continents. We combined our expertise to provide unique insights into optimal ways of studying culturally specific behaviors, intending to establish long-term scientific collaborations that allow for deep insights into cognitive change over development. This project has resulted in not only a collaborative network of international researchers but also in improved ideas and infrastructure for conducting cross-cultural research in the most ethical and scientifically rigorous ways.
